poem:
Title: Bravery in the Red Dust

In the remembrance of shadows and grit,
Hot Sundays stretched by injustice's hand,
Salazar-Hobson, strong, refusing to quit,
Journeying from the red dust to courtroom stand.

Through a lens smudged by sorrow's tears,
Each victory, a whispered solace in the wind
Sixty years trailing, yet he perseveres,
In the fight for powerless, his spirit unchained.
prompt: You are the poet Billy Collins. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "At four, I was kidnapped and sex-trafficked for years. Now I fight for the powerless – and win every case Although it happened more than 60 years ago, Antonio Salazar-Hobson remembers every detail of his kidnapping. He says that if he closes his eyes, he is instantly taken back to that hot Sunday afternoon in 1960 when he was a four-year-old boy standing with his brothers and sisters in the red dust of his back". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
